title: Iranian missiles strike Haifa as Israeli air force attacks Tehran
description: The Iranian and Israeli strikes mark the most sustained, direct attacks ever between the two rivals. Three people were killed in Israel and at least 78 in Iran, officials said.
author: Frances Vinall, Victoria Bisset, Vivian Ho
byline: Frances Vinall, Victoria Bisset, Vivian Ho, Mikhail Klimentov, Mohamad El Chamaa, Mustafa Salim, Alon Rom, Lior Soroka, Michael Birnbaum, Karen DeYoung, Nilo Tabrizy, Evan Hill, Warren P. Strobel, Heidi Levine, Joy Sung, Victoria Craw, Kareem Fahim, Adam Taylor, Susannah George, Matt Viser, Dan Lamothe, Alex Horton, Gerry Shih, Jintak Han
excerpt: The Iranian and Israeli strikes mark the most sustained, direct attacks ever between the two rivals. Three people were killed in Israel and at least 78 in Iran, officials said.
text: Iran and Israel traded strikes Saturday evening local time, with sirens ringing out in the Israeli city of Haifa and the Israeli Air Force announcing attacks on Tehran. The strikes represent the most sustained, direct attacks ever between the two regional rivals. Earlier in the day, strikes were reported in central Israel and Tel Aviv, while Iranian media reported explosions in eastern Tehran and in the vicinity of Mehrabad International Airport. Though nuclear talks between the U.S. and Iran were set to take place Sunday in Oman, the foreign minister of Oman said Saturday that they would be delayed. The latest fighting began last week when Israel launched an attack that killed senior Iranian military leaders and nuclear scientists.Live coverage contributors 24Return to menuJust before midnight local time, the Israeli military lifted its recommendation that citizens stay sheltered. Still, the latest assessment advised people to remain near safe locations.Return to menuSyria, Jordan and Iraq have all announced the closures of their airspace after Iranian missiles struck Haifa. In Lebanon, incoming and outgoing flights were canceled after Iranian projectiles were spotted in the Beirut sky.Return to menuHaifa, the target of Iranian missiles Saturday evening, is the site of a major naval base, oil refineries and numerous chemical plants.Missiles also appeared to hit some cities north of Haifa, with rescue services saying one person was critically injured in the attack.Return to menuIran launched missiles at Israel on Saturday evening local time, and explosions could be heard in the northern city of Haifa.The Israel Defense Forces announced that the Israeli Air Force was working to intercept the missiles, while also launching new strikes on Tehran.Return to menuThe Israel Defense Forces issued a new warning Saturday evening local time, asking residents to stay close to shelters.“Movement in public areas should be minimized, and public gatherings must be avoided,” reads the announcement. No immediate threat was identified.U.S. hopes Iran returns to negotiations, U.S. officials sayReturn to menuDespite the fighting between Israel and Iran, the United States remains committed to negotiations and hopes Iran “will come to the table soon,” said one senior U.S. official, speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss sensitive negotiations.That sentiment was echoed in a White House statement calling on Iran to give up its nuclear weapons program.Return to menuAli Shamkhani, an adviser to Iranian Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei, died of injuries sustained in an Israeli strike, Iranian media reported Saturday.Shamkhani was the Secretary General of Iran’s Supreme National Security Council, and one of a handful of Iranian officials who would speak with Western media.Return to menuPresident Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin discussed Israel’s conflict with Iran in a phone conversation Saturday, according to Kremlin foreign affairs adviser Yuri Ushakov.Ushakov told Russian media that both Trump and Putin expressed an interest in returning to peaceful negotiations over Iran’s nuclear program.Return to menuTalks between the United States and Iran that were scheduled to take place in Oman on Sunday have been called off, said Oman’s Foreign Minister Badr Al Busaidi. He cautioned that “diplomacy and dialogue remain the only pathway to lasting peace” in a post on X.Return to menuIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu praised the results of the Israeli strikes on Iran in recorded remarks Saturday, promising that Israel’s “pilots over the skies of Tehran will deal blows to the Ayatollah regime that they cannot even imagine.”Earlier Saturday, Iran shot down an Israeli F-35 over western Iran, according to reports in Iranian media.Netanyahu’s remarks, which centered on Israel’s relationship with the United States, also included birthday congratulations to President Donald Trump.Iran’s nuclear facilities damaged but not destroyed, experts say Return to menuIsrael’s airstrikes on Iran’s nuclear sites have damaged some aboveground research facilities and infrastructure but do not appear to have eliminated the thousands of centrifuges, buried deep underground, that enrich near-weapons-grade uranium or the hundreds of pounds of material they have already produced, according to a wide range of nonproliferation and Iranian experts.This is an excerpt from a full story.Fighting between Israel and Iran likely to last weeks, experts warnReturn to menuThe conflict between Israel and Iran could last weeks, if not longer, two experts warned.The first round of airstrikes hit Friday. But Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has been calling for the denuclearization of Iran for decades, said Fawaz Gerges, a professor of international relations at the London School of Economics.Israeli attacks could push Iran closer toward weaponization, experts sayReturn to menuIsrael’s attacks on Iran will lead to some factions in Iran pushing harder for weaponizing the country’s nuclear capabilities, two experts warned Saturday.Scenes from central Israel after Iranian missile barrageReturn to menuResidents in Rishon LeZion in central Israel inspected the damage at their homes after Iran’s missile barrages early Saturday.Weizman Raphael and his wife, Sharon, sifted through photos at the home of his mother, Burina, who sustained a head injury in the attack.Three people were killed in the Iranian missile strikes overnight, according to the emergency services — including two in Rishon LeZion.Video: Israelis assess damage, evacuate sites after missile strikesReturn to menuEmergency services were at the scene of missile strikes in Rishon LeZion on June 14 as Iran and Israel targeted each other with airstrikes. (Video: Reuters, Photo: Heidi Levine/Reuters)Emergency services and paramedics were at the scene of missile strikes in Rishon LeZion, Israel, on Saturday as Iran and Israel targeted each other with airstrikes.IDF says it has struck more than 150 targets in IranReturn to menuThe Israel Defense Forces said they were continuing strikes on Iran, and had hit more than 150 targets, in a statement Saturday.IDF Brig. Gen. Effie Defrin also said Israeli jets neutralized Iran’s air defenses overnight, allowing their aircraft to fly freely over Iran.The claims could not be independently verified.While the exact death toll in Iran is unclear, Iran’s ambassador to the United Nations previously said that 78 people had been killed and 320 wounded in Israeli strikes Friday.Return to menuIran’s foreign minister appeared to rule out continuing nuclear talks with the United States after Israel’s attacks.Iran and the U.S. were set to meet for negotiations in Oman on Sunday. But in comments reported by Iran’s state broadcaster on Saturday, Seyed Abbas Araghchi said that President Donald Trump’s statements led him to consider Israel’s actions “to be the result of direct support from Washington,” adding that the continuation of talks would be “unjustifiable.”While he did not specify which of Trump’s statements he was referring to, the president told ABC News on Friday that the attacks had been “excellent” and suggested that there were “more to come.”What we know about Iranian commanders, scientists killed in Israeli attackReturn to menuTehran on Friday confirmed the deaths of senior commanders and nuclear scientists after Israel’s attacks on targets across Iran.Here’s what we know about some key figures killed in the strikes.This is an excerpt from a full story.Return to menuIran launched multiple waves of fresh missile barrages at Israel early Saturday, while Israel continued airstrikes on Iran. (Video: Reuters)In Tel Aviv on Saturday afternoon, the streets are empty and there are hardly any cars. Israel’s Home Front Command has told residents it is not necessary to remain near a protected space for now — but people are opting to stay home, close to shelters or safe rooms, anticipating that a further wave of attacks from Iran could come at any moment.Israel claims significant damage to two Iranian nuclear sitesReturn to menuTwo key nuclear sites were “significantly damaged” in Israeli strikes on Iran, an Israeli military official said Saturday, while an Iranian official downplayed any impact on its nuclear facilities.Iran casts doubt on Sunday’s talks with U.S. on nuclear dealReturn to menuIt is not clear whether Iranian officials will agree to continue nuclear discussions with the United States, which had been scheduled for Sunday in Oman, following Israel’s attacks which killed a slew of Iran’s senior commanders and nuclear scientists on Friday.Esmaeil Baghaei, a spokesperson for Iran’s Foreign Ministry, told state-run media on Saturday that it was “still unclear what decision we will make” on Sunday’s talks.Tehran reportedly threatens to attack bases of countries that help IsraelReturn to menuTehran has warned the United States, Britain and France that it will target the military bases and ships of any country that helps repel Iranian attacks against Israel, Iran’s semiofficial Mehr news agency reported Saturday.Israeli defense minister says ‘Tehran will burn’ if missiles continueReturn to menuIsrael’s Defense Minister Israel Katz threatened that “Tehran will burn” if Iran continues to fire missiles toward Israel.“The Iranian dictator is turning the citizens of Iran into hostages, creating a reality in which they — especially the residents of Tehran — will pay a heavy price for the criminal attacks on Israeli civilians,” Katz said in a statement Saturday. “If Khamenei continues firing missiles at Israel’s home front — Tehran will burn.”Trump pledged peace but is now embroiled in new Israel-Iran conflict Return to menuPresident Donald Trump swept into office vowing to end wars around the world, but his efforts to strike a nuclear deal with Iran appear to have spurred Israel to start a new one, as the U.S. military on Friday helped shoot down Iranian missiles headed toward Israeli territory.This is an excerpt from a full story.Return to menuWhile the exact death toll in Iran is still unclear, the state broadcaster reported Saturday that around 60 people had been killed in an Israeli strike early Friday on a 14-floor residential building in Shahid Chamran town. A television reporter said the toll from local authorities included 20 children, including 10 still buried under the rubble.Iran’s ambassador to the United Nations previously said that 78 people were killed and 320 wounded in the Israeli strikes, without providing a breakdown of civilian or military casualties.Return to menuFlights at all Iranian airports are suspended until further notice, according to an announcement issued by Iran’s civil aviation body and shared Saturday by Iranian media. Iranian media reported explosions overnight in the vicinity of the Mehrabad International Airport, in the capital.Return to menuPatriot and THAAD missile defense batteries, operated by U.S. military personnel and originally deployed under the Biden administration, participated in Israeli air defense Friday evening, according to U.S. defense officials who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss the sensitive subject. That represented a more limited participation in Israel’s defense than last year, when American air and sea assets helped shoot down incoming Iranian missiles during two retaliatory Iranian attacks.Return to menuIran on Saturday announced the killing of two senior military commanders. A military statement shared by state broadcaster IRIB said Gholamreza Mehrabi, deputy head of intelligence for the armed forces general staff, and Mehdi Rabbani, deputy head of operations for the armed forces general staff died following Israel’s “brutal aggression.”Return to menuIn neighboring Syria, citizens have been warned not to gather on rooftops to monitor developments. On Friday, the remnants of two Iranian missiles fell in the southwestern Syrian province of Daraa, without causing any damage or casualties, state media reported.Return to menuAt least 78 people were killed and 320 injured in Israeli strikes across Iran early Friday, said Iran’s ambassador to the United Nations. It was not immediately clear how many were civilians, versus military personnel.Israel hails success of Iran strikes, but strategic aims still elusiveReturn to menuJERUSALEM — As the sun rose over Tehran on Friday, the startling scale of Israel’s surprise attack on Iran became evident: Israeli forces, supported by a covert Mossad operation months in the making, severely damaged the Iranian nuclear facility at Natanz, destroyed some of Iran’s ballistic missile arsenal and killed half a dozen senior Iranian military leaders and nuclear scientists in a flurry of 100 airstrikes.This is an excerpt from a full story.Return to menuSirens sounded in several areas across northern Israel as Iran launched a fresh round of missiles early Saturday, the Israel Defense Forces said. Shortly afterward, it issued an all-clear to leave shelters but asked Israelis to remain near them.Return to menuExplosions were heard in two neighborhoods in eastern Tehran shortly after 4 a.m. local time, reported the country’s semiofficial Tasnim News Agency, which is linked to the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps. The agency shared video of smoke pouring from behind buildings.Iran retaliates against Israel with barrage of ballistic missilesReturn to menuIran unleashed a barrage of ballistic missiles at Israel late Friday and early Saturday as it retaliated for the waves of Israeli strikes that killed top military leaders and nuclear scientists, and damaged a key uranium enrichment site.This is an excerpt from a full story.At least 3 killed in Israel since attacks beganReturn to menuAt least three people have been killed in Israel during Iranian missile barrages since Friday. Two people were killed in central Israel early Saturday and a woman who was injured in a suburb near Tel Aviv on Friday later died in a hospital, a spokesperson for Beilinson Hospital said.
html:
Iran and Israel traded strikes Saturday evening local time, with sirens ringing out in the Israeli city of Haifa and the Israeli Air Force announcing attacks on Tehran. The strikes represent the most sustained, direct attacks ever between the two regional rivals. Earlier in the day, strikes were reported in central Israel and Tel Aviv, while Iranian media reported explosions in eastern Tehran and in the vicinity of Mehrabad International Airport. Though nuclear talks between the U.S. and Iran were set to take place Sunday in Oman, the foreign minister of Oman said Saturday that they would be delayed. The latest fighting began last week when Israel launched an attack that killed senior Iranian military leaders and nuclear scientists.

Live coverage contributors 24

  • Return to menu

    Just before midnight local time, the Israeli military lifted its recommendation that citizens stay sheltered. Still, the latest assessment advised people to remain near safe locations.

  • Return to menu

    Syria, Jordan and Iraq have all announced the closures of their airspace after Iranian missiles struck Haifa. In Lebanon, incoming and outgoing flights were canceled after Iranian projectiles were spotted in the Beirut sky.

  • Return to menu

    Haifa, the target of Iranian missiles Saturday evening, is the site of a major naval base, oil refineries and numerous chemical plants.

    Missiles also appeared to hit some cities north of Haifa, with rescue services saying one person was critically injured in the attack.

  • Return to menu

    Iran launched missiles at Israel on Saturday evening local time, and explosions could be heard in the northern city of Haifa.

    The Israel Defense Forces announced that the Israeli Air Force was working to intercept the missiles, while also launching new strikes on Tehran.

  • Return to menu

    The Israel Defense Forces issued a new warning Saturday evening local time, asking residents to stay close to shelters.

    “Movement in public areas should be minimized, and public gatherings must be avoided,” reads the announcement. No immediate threat was identified.

  • U.S. hopes Iran returns to negotiations, U.S. officials say

    Return to menu

    Despite the fighting between Israel and Iran, the United States remains committed to negotiations and hopes Iran “will come to the table soon,” said one senior U.S. official, speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss sensitive negotiations.

    That sentiment was echoed in a White House statement calling on Iran to give up its nuclear weapons program.

  • Return to menu

    Ali Shamkhani, an adviser to Iranian Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei, died of injuries sustained in an Israeli strike, Iranian media reported Saturday.

    Shamkhani was the Secretary General of Iran’s Supreme National Security Council, and one of a handful of Iranian officials who would speak with Western media.

  • Return to menu

    President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin discussed Israel’s conflict with Iran in a phone conversation Saturday, according to Kremlin foreign affairs adviser Yuri Ushakov.

    Ushakov told Russian media that both Trump and Putin expressed an interest in returning to peaceful negotiations over Iran’s nuclear program.

  • Return to menu

    Talks between the United States and Iran that were scheduled to take place in Oman on Sunday have been called off, said Oman’s Foreign Minister Badr Al Busaidi. He cautioned that “diplomacy and dialogue remain the only pathway to lasting peace” in a post on X.

  • Return to menu

    Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu praised the results of the Israeli strikes on Iran in recorded remarks Saturday, promising that Israel’s “pilots over the skies of Tehran will deal blows to the Ayatollah regime that they cannot even imagine.”

    Earlier Saturday, Iran shot down an Israeli F-35 over western Iran, according to reports in Iranian media.

    Netanyahu’s remarks, which centered on Israel’s relationship with the United States, also included birthday congratulations to President Donald Trump.

  • Iran’s nuclear facilities damaged but not destroyed, experts say

    Return to menu

    Israel’s airstrikes on Iran’s nuclear sites have damaged some aboveground research facilities and infrastructure but do not appear to have eliminated the thousands of centrifuges, buried deep underground, that enrich near-weapons-grade uranium or the hundreds of pounds of material they have already produced, according to a wide range of nonproliferation and Iranian experts.

    This is an excerpt from a full story.

  • Fighting between Israel and Iran likely to last weeks, experts warn

    Return to menu

    The conflict between Israel and Iran could last weeks, if not longer, two experts warned.

    The first round of airstrikes hit Friday. But Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has been calling for the denuclearization of Iran for decades, said Fawaz Gerges, a professor of international relations at the London School of Economics.

  • Israeli attacks could push Iran closer toward weaponization, experts say

    Return to menu

    Israel’s attacks on Iran will lead to some factions in Iran pushing harder for weaponizing the country’s nuclear capabilities, two experts warned Saturday.

  • Scenes from central Israel after Iranian missile barrage

    Return to menu

    Residents in Rishon LeZion in central Israel inspected the damage at their homes after Iran’s missile barrages early Saturday.

    Weizman Raphael and his wife, Sharon, sifted through photos at the home of his mother, Burina, who sustained a head injury in the attack.

    Three people were killed in the Iranian missile strikes overnight, according to the emergency services — including two in Rishon LeZion.

  • Video: Israelis assess damage, evacuate sites after missile strikes

    Return to menu

    Emergency services and paramedics were at the scene of missile strikes in Rishon LeZion, Israel, on Saturday as Iran and Israel targeted each other with airstrikes.

  • IDF says it has struck more than 150 targets in Iran

    Return to menu

    The Israel Defense Forces said they were continuing strikes on Iran, and had hit more than 150 targets, in a statement Saturday.

    IDF Brig. Gen. Effie Defrin also said Israeli jets neutralized Iran’s air defenses overnight, allowing their aircraft to fly freely over Iran.

    The claims could not be independently verified.

    While the exact death toll in Iran is unclear, Iran’s ambassador to the United Nations previously said that 78 people had been killed and 320 wounded in Israeli strikes Friday.

  • Return to menu

    Iran’s foreign minister appeared to rule out continuing nuclear talks with the United States after Israel’s attacks.

    Iran and the U.S. were set to meet for negotiations in Oman on Sunday. But in comments reported by Iran’s state broadcaster on Saturday, Seyed Abbas Araghchi said that President Donald Trump’s statements led him to consider Israel’s actions “to be the result of direct support from Washington,” adding that the continuation of talks would be “unjustifiable.”

    While he did not specify which of Trump’s statements he was referring to, the president told ABC News on Friday that the attacks had been “excellent” and suggested that there were “more to come.”

  • What we know about Iranian commanders, scientists killed in Israeli attack

    Return to menu

    Tehran on Friday confirmed the deaths of senior commanders and nuclear scientists after Israel’s attacks on targets across Iran.

    Here’s what we know about some key figures killed in the strikes.

    This is an excerpt from a full story.

  • Return to menu

    In Tel Aviv on Saturday afternoon, the streets are empty and there are hardly any cars. Israel’s Home Front Command has told residents it is not necessary to remain near a protected space for now — but people are opting to stay home, close to shelters or safe rooms, anticipating that a further wave of attacks from Iran could come at any moment.

  • Israel claims significant damage to two Iranian nuclear sites

    Return to menu

    Two key nuclear sites were “significantly damaged” in Israeli strikes on Iran, an Israeli military official said Saturday, while an Iranian official downplayed any impact on its nuclear facilities.

  • Iran casts doubt on Sunday’s talks with U.S. on nuclear deal

    Return to menu

    It is not clear whether Iranian officials will agree to continue nuclear discussions with the United States, which had been scheduled for Sunday in Oman, following Israel’s attacks which killed a slew of Iran’s senior commanders and nuclear scientists on Friday.

    Esmaeil Baghaei, a spokesperson for Iran’s Foreign Ministry, told state-run media on Saturday that it was “still unclear what decision we will make” on Sunday’s talks.

  • Tehran reportedly threatens to attack bases of countries that help Israel

    Return to menu

    Tehran has warned the United States, Britain and France that it will target the military bases and ships of any country that helps repel Iranian attacks against Israel, Iran’s semiofficial Mehr news agency reported Saturday.

  • Israeli defense minister says ‘Tehran will burn’ if missiles continue

    Return to menu

    Israel’s Defense Minister Israel Katz threatened that “Tehran will burn” if Iran continues to fire missiles toward Israel.

    “The Iranian dictator is turning the citizens of Iran into hostages, creating a reality in which they — especially the residents of Tehran — will pay a heavy price for the criminal attacks on Israeli civilians,” Katz said in a statement Saturday. “If Khamenei continues firing missiles at Israel’s home front — Tehran will burn.”

  • Trump pledged peace but is now embroiled in new Israel-Iran conflict

    Return to menu

    President Donald Trump swept into office vowing to end wars around the world, but his efforts to strike a nuclear deal with Iran appear to have spurred Israel to start a new one, as the U.S. military on Friday helped shoot down Iranian missiles headed toward Israeli territory.

    This is an excerpt from a full story.

  • Return to menu

    While the exact death toll in Iran is still unclear, the state broadcaster reported Saturday that around 60 people had been killed in an Israeli strike early Friday on a 14-floor residential building in Shahid Chamran town. A television reporter said the toll from local authorities included 20 children, including 10 still buried under the rubble.

    Iran’s ambassador to the United Nations previously said that 78 people were killed and 320 wounded in the Israeli strikes, without providing a breakdown of civilian or military casualties.

  • Return to menu

    Flights at all Iranian airports are suspended until further notice, according to an announcement issued by Iran’s civil aviation body and shared Saturday by Iranian media. Iranian media reported explosions overnight in the vicinity of the Mehrabad International Airport, in the capital.

  • Return to menu

    Patriot and THAAD missile defense batteries, operated by U.S. military personnel and originally deployed under the Biden administration, participated in Israeli air defense Friday evening, according to U.S. defense officials who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss the sensitive subject. That represented a more limited participation in Israel’s defense than last year, when American air and sea assets helped shoot down incoming Iranian missiles during two retaliatory Iranian attacks.

  • Return to menu

    Iran on Saturday announced the killing of two senior military commanders. A military statement shared by state broadcaster IRIB said Gholamreza Mehrabi, deputy head of intelligence for the armed forces general staff, and Mehdi Rabbani, deputy head of operations for the armed forces general staff died following Israel’s “brutal aggression.”

  • Return to menu

    In neighboring Syria, citizens have been warned not to gather on rooftops to monitor developments. On Friday, the remnants of two Iranian missiles fell in the southwestern Syrian province of Daraa, without causing any damage or casualties, state media reported.

  • Return to menu

    At least 78 people were killed and 320 injured in Israeli strikes across Iran early Friday, said Iran’s ambassador to the United Nations. It was not immediately clear how many were civilians, versus military personnel.

  • Israel hails success of Iran strikes, but strategic aims still elusive

    Return to menu

    JERUSALEM — As the sun rose over Tehran on Friday, the startling scale of Israel’s surprise attack on Iran became evident: Israeli forces, supported by a covert Mossad operation months in the making, severely damaged the Iranian nuclear facility at Natanz, destroyed some of Iran’s ballistic missile arsenal and killed half a dozen senior Iranian military leaders and nuclear scientists in a flurry of 100 airstrikes.

    This is an excerpt from a full story.

  • Return to menu

    Sirens sounded in several areas across northern Israel as Iran launched a fresh round of missiles early Saturday, the Israel Defense Forces said. Shortly afterward, it issued an all-clear to leave shelters but asked Israelis to remain near them.

  • Return to menu

    Explosions were heard in two neighborhoods in eastern Tehran shortly after 4 a.m. local time, reported the country’s semiofficial Tasnim News Agency, which is linked to the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps. The agency shared video of smoke pouring from behind buildings.

  • Iran retaliates against Israel with barrage of ballistic missiles

    Return to menu

    Iran unleashed a barrage of ballistic missiles at Israel late Friday and early Saturday as it retaliated for the waves of Israeli strikes that killed top military leaders and nuclear scientists, and damaged a key uranium enrichment site.

    This is an excerpt from a full story.

  • At least 3 killed in Israel since attacks began

    Return to menu

    At least three people have been killed in Israel during Iranian missile barrages since Friday. Two people were killed in central Israel early Saturday and a woman who was injured in a suburb near Tel Aviv on Friday later died in a hospital, a spokesperson for Beilinson Hospital said.
